steps.title: Company Overview
steps.content:
Akumin Inc. operates a network of approximately 200 outpatient diagnostic imaging centers across the United States, generating approximately $450M in annual revenue from radiology services. The company delivers over 3.2 million imaging procedures annually through a distributed network spanning Florida, Texas, Delaware, Pennsylvania, and several other states. Services include MRI, CT, PET/CT, ultrasound, and X-ray examinations performed under contracts with health systems, insurance payers, and referring physicians.

The business operates through two primary revenue streams: fixed-site imaging centers (78% of revenue) and mobile imaging services (22% of revenue). Payer mix includes commercial insurance (52%), Medicare (31%), Medicaid (9%), and self-pay (8%). Average reimbursement per procedure stands at $141 with collection rates of 94% on contracted volumes. Radiologist interpretation costs represent 38% of procedure revenue, while technologist labor accounts for 24%.

The company faces a $34M annual burden from prior authorization workflows. Insurance verification and authorization processes consume 87,000 hours per year across administrative staff managing 1.9 million authorization requests with 23% requiring resubmission. This workload creates an average 4.2-day delay between physician order and scheduled appointment, contributing to 14% patient no-show rates and $8M in lost procedure revenue. Manual claims adjudication adds $19M in processing costs, with billing specialists spending 52,000 hours annually resolving denials and coding discrepancies across 847 different payer-specific rules.

Radiology report generation represents a $12M efficiency gap. Radiologists spend an average 8.2 minutes per report on template selection, structured findings documentation, and comparison dictation across multiple prior studies. At 2.8 million reports annually and $185 per hour fully-loaded radiologist costs, this represents 382,000 hours of professional time. Report turnaround time averages 14.3 hours from procedure completion to final signature, with stat reports requiring 2.1 hours. Referring physicians cite slow report delivery as the primary factor in routing cases to competitor facilities.

Scheduling optimization presents a $7M opportunity cost. Centers operate at 67% capacity utilization during off-peak hours while peak slots reach 94% utilization, creating artificial scarcity. Manual scheduling processes cannot dynamically rebalance demand across the network, resulting in 340,000 annual cases scheduled beyond 7-day windows when same-day or next-day slots exist at nearby facilities. Equipment downtime for maintenance averages 9.3% of available scanner hours, often scheduled during periods that analysis would reveal as high-demand windows.

Financial figures derive from Akumin's 2023 annual report and Q3 2024 earnings releases filed with Canadian securities regulators. Operational burden estimates apply $150 per hour for administrative staff, $185 per hour for radiologists, and $85 per hour for technologists based on industry compensation surveys. Data maturity assessed at Level 2 based on disclosed legacy RIS and PACS systems with limited interoperability and manual workaround prevalence described in operational commentary.

steps.title: Business Function Inventory & KPI Baselines
steps.content: Operational metrics reflect a maturing outpatient imaging network facing typical industry challenges in utilization, throughput, and reimbursement optimization.

data.Friction Point: Manual compilation of clinical documentation across fragmented EHR, PACS, and RIS systems for 1.9M annual authorization requests with 23% requiring resubmission due to incomplete supporting evidence
Payer-specific coding rules across 847 unique payer contracts require manual cross-referencing, causing 19% initial denial rate and 52K hours annually resolving appeals
Radiologists manually search PACS archives for relevant priors, transcribe comparison findings, and populate structured report templates consuming 8.2 minutes per study
Call center staff lack real-time visibility into network-wide slot availability, resulting in 340K procedures scheduled beyond 7 days when earlier slots exist at nearby centers
Appeals require manual research of payer medical policies, assembly of supporting literature, and customized narrative drafting with 42% of denials never appealed due to workload constraints
Maintenance schedules set manually without consideration of demand patterns, resulting in 9.3% downtime during high-utilization windows and underutilization during scheduled availability
Manual sampling audits cover only 3% of procedures, missing systematic coding errors until external audits trigger corrective action plans and potential repayment obligations
Critical findings identification triggers manual phone calls to referring physicians with documentation in separate system, averaging 47 minutes from finding to confirmed communication
Benefits verification requires logging into multiple payer portals with inconsistent interfaces, consuming 3.8 minutes per verification and causing 11% accuracy errors
Patient responsibility estimation errors due to complex deductible and coinsurance calculations result in 23% of collections requiring post-service adjustments and rework
Radiologists receive cases without contextual clinical information from referring providers, requiring additional research or generating non-specific findings that trigger callback requests
Appointment reminders and prep instructions sent via single channel with 14% no-show rate partially attributable to inadequate multi-touch confirmation workflows

steps.title: Friction Point Mapping
steps.content: Operational bottlenecks concentrate in three domains: revenue cycle administration where manual processes create delays and errors, clinical documentation where radiologist time constraints limit throughput, and network optimization where demand-supply matching fails without intelligent routing.

data.Description: AI system automatically retrieves relevant clinical documentation from EHR, RIS, and PACS based on payer-specific authorization requirements, assembles complete authorization packets with supporting evidence, and drafts clinical justification narratives mapped to medical necessity criteria. System learns from approval patterns to optimize documentation completeness.
data.AI Primitives: Research & Information Retrieval, Content Creation, Workflow Automation
data.Target Friction: Manual compilation of clinical documentation across fragmented systems for 1.9M annual authorization requests with 23% resubmission rate
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Authorization specialist reviews AI-assembled packet for completeness and clinical appropriateness before submission, with particular focus on complex cases involving experimental protocols or off-label indications

data.Description: System analyzes procedure documentation and automatically applies correct CPT and ICD-10 codes based on payer-specific requirements across 847 unique contracts. Flags potential denials before submission based on pattern recognition from historical claims data. Suggests documentation additions to support code selection.
data.AI Primitives: Data Analysis, Workflow Automation, Research & Information Retrieval
data.Target Friction: Payer-specific coding rules require manual cross-referencing, causing 19% initial denial rate and 52K hours resolving appeals
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Certified coder reviews AI coding recommendations for high-value procedures over $1,200 or cases flagged by system as having ambiguous documentation support

data.Description: AI drafts structured radiology reports by analyzing DICOM images, retrieving relevant prior studies, generating comparison language, and populating templated findings sections. Radiologist edits AI-generated draft, adds clinical interpretation, and signs final report. System learns radiologist preferences and adapts templates accordingly.
data.AI Primitives: Content Creation, Research & Information Retrieval, Data Analysis
data.Target Friction: Radiologists spend 8.2 minutes per report on template selection, structured findings documentation, and comparison dictation
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Radiologist reviews every AI-generated draft for clinical accuracy, edits findings as needed, adds interpretive commentary, and electronically signs report before release to ordering physician

data.Description: System analyzes real-time slot availability across 200-site network, patient location, modality requirements, and historical demand patterns to recommend optimal scheduling. Presents call center staff with ranked options balancing patient convenience and network utilization. Learns from scheduling outcomes to refine recommendations.
data.AI Primitives: Data Analysis, Workflow Automation, Conversational Interfaces
data.Target Friction: Call center staff lack network-wide visibility, resulting in 340K procedures scheduled beyond 7 days when earlier slots exist nearby
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Scheduling coordinator reviews AI recommendations and confirms final appointment with patient, overriding system suggestions when patient constraints or special circumstances require different placement

data.Description: AI analyzes denial reason codes, retrieves applicable payer medical policy language, identifies supporting clinical literature, and drafts customized appeal letters with regulatory citations. System prioritizes appeals by financial value and likelihood of overturn based on historical success rates.
data.AI Primitives: Research & Information Retrieval, Content Creation, Data Analysis
data.Target Friction: Appeals require manual research and narrative drafting with 42% of denials never appealed due to workload constraints
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Appeals specialist reviews AI-drafted appeal for clinical and regulatory accuracy, adds case-specific arguments, and approves submission, with particular scrutiny on appeals exceeding $5,000 value

data.Description: System analyzes historical demand patterns, equipment utilization trends, and maintenance requirements to recommend optimal maintenance windows that minimize revenue impact. Forecasts demand by modality, day-of-week, and location to identify low-utilization periods for preventive service.
data.Target Friction: Manual maintenance scheduling causes 9.3% downtime during high-demand windows and underutilization during available periods
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Facilities manager reviews AI-recommended maintenance schedule, verifies compatibility with service provider availability and clinical priorities, and approves final calendar

data.Description: AI continuously scans 100% of submitted claims against regulatory requirements, payer policies, and historical audit findings to identify potential compliance issues. Flags high-risk patterns for investigation such as upcoding trends, unbundling, or medical necessity gaps. Generates monthly compliance scorecards by facility and provider.
data.Target Friction: Manual sampling audits cover only 3% of procedures, missing systematic errors until external audits trigger corrective action
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Compliance officer reviews flagged claims, investigates root causes of identified patterns, determines appropriate corrective action, and decides whether to self-report or implement process changes

data.Description: System detects critical findings in radiology reports based on structured data and natural language analysis, automatically initiates multi-channel notification to referring physician, tracks confirmation receipt, and escalates unacknowledged alerts according to protocol. Documents complete communication chain in EHR.
data.AI Primitives: Workflow Automation, Conversational Interfaces, Data Analysis
data.Target Friction: Critical findings require manual phone calls with separate documentation, averaging 47 minutes from identification to confirmed communication
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Radiologist confirms critical finding classification before automated notification initiates, and clinical coordinator reviews escalation outcomes to verify appropriate physician contact achieved

data.Description: AI agent logs into payer portals, retrieves current benefit information, extracts deductible status and authorization requirements, and populates structured verification records. Handles variations in portal interfaces and authentication requirements across hundreds of payers. Flags discrepancies for manual review.
data.AI Primitives: Workflow Automation, Research & Information Retrieval, Data Analysis
data.Target Friction: Benefits verification requires manual portal access consuming 3.8 minutes per verification with 11% accuracy errors
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Patient access representative reviews AI-retrieved benefit information for high-value procedures exceeding $3,000 or when system flags low-confidence results, confirming coverage before scheduling

data.Description: System calculates patient financial responsibility by analyzing verified benefits, procedure costs, deductible status, coinsurance percentages, and out-of-pocket maximums. Generates accurate estimates for point-of-service collection and reduces post-service billing adjustments. Learns from actual payment patterns to refine estimates.
data.Target Friction: Complex deductible calculations result in 23% of collections requiring post-service adjustments and rework
data.Human-in-the-Loop Checkpoint: Financial counselor reviews estimates for procedures exceeding $1,500 patient responsibility, confirms calculation logic, and discusses payment options with patient before service

analysis.summary:
This assessment identifies $90.8M in annual value across 10 AI use cases targeting Akumin's diagnostic imaging operations. Three initiatives qualify as Critical-priority for immediate Q1-Q2 deployment with combined first-year impact of $27.3M. The portfolio concentrates on revenue cycle transformation where manual processes create $34M in annual friction across prior authorization, claims management, and denial appeals workflows.

Cost reduction dominates the value composition at $42.0M, representing 46% of total identified value. Revenue growth opportunities contribute $26.7M at 29%. Risk mitigation accounts for $13.0M at 14%. Cash flow acceleration rounds out the portfolio at $9.1M representing 10%. This distribution reflects deliberate focus on back-office automation where data accessibility and process standardization enable faster deployment compared to patient-facing applications requiring behavioral change management.

Payer-Adaptive Claims Coding Assistant represents a $14.1M annual opportunity through automated application of 847 unique payer-specific coding rules. The system reduces initial claim denial rates from 19% to 11% by validating code selection against payer medical policies before submission. Each percentage point improvement in first-pass acceptance generates $1.8M in avoided appeals labor and accelerated cash collection. Implementation requires integration with the existing billing system and a 90-day radiologist training program on AI-suggested code review protocols. Time-to-value reaches 7 months with moderate effort scores across data readiness and change management dimensions.

Automated Denial Appeals Drafter captures $13.2M annually by converting 42% of previously unworked denials into structured appeals with supporting clinical evidence and payer policy citations. The system drafts customized appeal letters by analyzing denial reason codes, retrieving applicable medical policy language, and identifying supporting peer-reviewed literature. Appeals specialists review AI-generated drafts before submission, focusing manual effort on high-value cases exceeding $5,000. Historical data indicates 14 percentage point improvement in overturn rates when appeals include policy-specific citations versus generic clinical narratives. The solution requires read-only access to the claims management database and bidirectional integration with payer appeal submission portals.

Radiology Report Generation Accelerator delivers $12.8M through AI-drafted structured reports that reduce radiologist documentation time from 8.2 minutes to 4.8 minutes per study. The system analyzes DICOM images, retrieves relevant prior examinations, generates comparison language, and populates templated findings sections that radiologists edit and sign. Throughput gains enable 5.5-hour reduction in average report turnaround time from the current 14.3-hour baseline. Faster delivery strengthens competitive positioning with referring physicians who cite slow report availability as a primary factor in routing cases to alternative facilities. Implementation spans 10 months including PACS integration, radiologist preference learning cycles, and liability review with medical malpractice carriers.

The top three initiatives account for 44% of total portfolio value, creating concentration risk if any single deployment encounters technical obstacles or adoption resistance. However, each targets a distinct operational domain with different stakeholder groups, providing natural portfolio hedging. Back-office automation opportunities outnumber patient-facing initiatives 8 to 2, deliberately prioritizing areas where AI can operate with higher autonomy and lower regulatory scrutiny. Revenue cycle use cases cluster together, enabling shared infrastructure investments in payer connectivity and claims data normalization that reduce incremental deployment costs for later-stage initiatives.

Implementation hinges on normalizing data schemas across legacy RIS, PACS, and billing systems that currently operate with inconsistent patient identifiers and procedure coding taxonomies. Data readiness averaging Level 2 across target systems requires 120-day data mapping and governance sprint before AI model training begins. Schema inconsistencies reduce projected first-year value by 35% until remediation work establishes reliable data pipelines. Payer portal authentication represents a secondary risk for benefit verification and appeals submission use cases, with 23% of targeted payers lacking API access and requiring robotic process automation approaches that introduce brittleness. Failure to secure radiologist buy-in for report generation workflows poses adoption risk given historical resistance to clinical decision support tools perceived as constraining professional autonomy.
